column14: Each Observation resource represents an individual laboratory test and result value, a “nested” panel (such as a microbial susceptibility panel) which references other observations, or rarely a laboratory test with component result values. They can also be presented in report form or as free text.

It rarely represents a laboratory test with component result values. Laboratory results can also be presented in report form or as free text.

column14: The Human Readable Form (HRF) representation of the barcode string as printed on the packaging of the device SHALL be used. The AIDC representation cannot be conveyed in FHIR, Because of limitations on character sets in XML and the need to round-trip JSON data through XML.

column16:
The CCDS (https://www.healthit.gov/sites/default/files/topiclanding/2018-04/2015Ed_CCG_CCDS.pdf) require the use of a "procedure" - as the context for an implant. Since the CCDA 2.1 already supports the surrounding procedure, it's useful to provide the same contextual information through a FHIR "search".

"Exchanging unique device identifier(s) using the “Product Instance” which is
embedded in the “Procedure Activity Procedure” in the C-CDA Release 2.1 is
intended to make this information more easily retrievable. [see also 80 FR 62695]
Note that the 2015 Edition final rule refers to the “Procedure Activity Procedure
Section” and we clarify that this is not a Section.":
column17: Add an "Implant Procedure" profile to describe the context of an implantable device in the required implantable device list.
column25:
The current US-Core-Procedure does allow'focalDevice' which can reference a US-Core-Device.

The creation of a specific implant procedure profile is not necessary.

column16:
The following us-core-device "must support" data elements are missing:
+ Device.udiCarrier: "S", [1..1] for implantable devices
+ Device.udiCarrrier.deviceIdentifier - is mandatory, therefore the parent element has to be mandatory and it requires "S", [1..1]
+ Device.udiCarrier.HRFcarrier OR Device.udiCarrier.AIDCcarrier MAY be supported 
+ Device.distictIdentifier "S" [0..1] SHALL be supported for  HCT/P regulated as a device, the distinct identification code required by 21 CFR 1271.290(c).
+ Device.manufactureDate "S", [1..1]
+ Device.expirationDate "S", [1..1]
+ Device.lotNumber "S". [0..1] -  SHALL be supported  if the Production Identifier specifies a lot number
+ Device.serialNumber "S", [0..1] -  SHALL be supported if the Production Identifier specifies a serial number
column25: Discuss which elements need to be must support vs mandatory

column14:
"+ Query for a Patient’s Devices
 + Record a Patient Device"
column15:
"+ Query for a Patient’s Implantable  Devices consistent with the MU2-15 certification criteria
+ Record a Patient's Implant, Prosthetics, Durable Medical Equipment,  etc."
column16: It would be useful to define a generic "us-device" and perhaps create a separate "implantable-us-device". This would avoid the issue that this profile specification does not currently support the narrow/specific criteria set in the MU2015 certification and it's not aligned with C-CDA 2.1.
column17: Clarify this profile is intended to provide - primarily  - access to the implantable device list managed by an EHR or another type of information system.

column15: This profile sets minimum expectations for the Device resource to record, search and fetch  information associated with a device or tissue product implanted in a patient and subject to UDI regulation. It identifies which core elements, vocabularies and value sets SHALL be present in the resource when using this profile.

column16: Patient Profile-3. a gender: maintaining a distinction between administrative labeling of gender and clinical labeling is becoming increasingly problematic-see American Family Physician: 2018 Dec 1;98(11):645-653 ref the importance of getting the details right. The posture of separating clinical and administrative duties maintains silos in healthcare that should be reconciled and harmonized.
column17: Consider implications of keeping administrative gender and clinical labeling separate.
column25:
Current guidance from ONC requires Birth Sex, which is a separate item from Administraive Gender and Clinical labeling. 

Standard currently supports requirement of regulation. We encourage harmonization and agreement at policy level for standard to follow.  Note that the footnote referencing the FHIR spec re gender is not rendering correctly.

column16: Medication profiles for patients are not well maintained so retrieval of a clean medication profile will be difficult until the maintenance of medication lists is significantly improved-if all entries are correctly made-retrieval according to this method should be easy-the challenge is gaining compliance on accurate and updated medication lists-the impact is that many citizens die each year due to medication errors, of which lists can be a contributing factor.
column17: Inaccurate Medication List
column25:
We completely agree. 

Our hope is exposing the underlying medication lists from EHRs through a FHIR API will allow other providers and patients to work together to keep these lists up-to-date.

column16: We need examples guidance for US implementers who need to adapt/constrain/extend the US-Core profiles for their implementation projects. For instance the VA and DoD will need to create extensions related to military service and service-related conditions. Therefore the VA will need to create profiles derived from these US-Core profiles. Similarly, the CRN-related IGs (e.g. WHT) have to create profiles/StructureDefinition resources to represent their constraints/extensions. The VA could contribute such as examples to help other US implementers.
column17: As examples of profiles derived from US-Core profiles and extensions (e.g. veteran-us-core-patient, us-military-service extension).
column25: If the VA and DoD is able to provide such examples we are happy to include in final publication.

column16: Implementers need guidance on how to use profile identifier to search for resources compatible with the display characteristics of their client application.  There are many data elements that could be included in a resource in the response bundle. However, the client applications are only mandated to display the must-support data elements. Are we expecting application to display other data elements? What should be the expectation of users/clinicians who use client applications that conform to this spec (i.e. the "requestor" actor0?
column17: Provide guidance to application that use FHIR to interrogate EHRs for resources conformant with US-Core. The current guidance focuses on the 'responder', primarily.
column25:
We believe additional elements may need to be displayed beyond those mandated in this specficiation. Defining display requirements is difficult and not something considered fully in this current tproject.

This is a great question and believe is appropriate for a future project.

column16:
Currently all the sample resources conforming to this IG are part of the "download" zip archive. Implementers would benefit from having each US-Core profile showing:
- two or more sample resource that conform to the profile
- one or more StructureDefinition derived from the current US-Core profile demonstrating a constraint or extension.
- provide the samples in-line with the profile (as a tab on the same page - similar tot he FHIR ballot)
The VA team is developing several profiles based on US-Core already and we would be happy to contribute them to illustrate the use of this IG .  We could help the project team add additional sample resources and sample  US-provider-specific profiles derived from the US-Core, that reuse US core extensions.
column17: Add additional sample resources and sample US-provider-specific profiles derived from the US-Core; show how to reuse US profiles and extensions.
column25:
Thank you for the offer. We would be happy to include additional VA samples that conform to these profiles which will be added to an examples to  https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/US-Core-R4/all-examples.html and a a note to the profiles where additional examples can be found.

Additional derived profiles may be appropriate in the general guidance, or inline, please provide for consideration.

column16:
This profile does not require query parameter "category", but this is the most helpful query parameter, as category is a rollup of many types that are in a single category.
Also, the new clinical-note seems to presume category (class) is included 
type is a much less well managed valueset accross any domain, as it needs to represent actual document type. Where category is a more controlled valueset due to the ability to group many types into one category.  (See IHE Metadata Handbook)
column17: Add support for Category in DocumentReference
column25: Will update category to 'must support' in DocumentReference when merge them

column14:
$docref
Typically, DocumentReference resources are used with document indexing systems, such as IHE XDS. However, document references may also may be created “on-the-fly” in response to a Document Query request. In other words there MAY NOT be pre-existing index of references to a patient’s documents at the FHIR endpoint. This results in an empty bundle being returned when searching using a normal FHIR Query. Therefore, the $docref operation has been defined to both create and fetch patient DocumentReference Resources.
column16:
It is very confusing the intention of the $docref operation. It seems to be a duplicate of the more simple RESTful query. The given text seems to indicate that it would be impossible to "create and fetch" during a RESTful query. This is not specifically true except in an architecture that has not-otherwise-specified ways. If there is a special reason for a client to choose to use $docref vs using query parameters, then this must be explained. If there is a special reason why a server would want $docref to be supported, then this must be explained. Without these explaination then $docref should be removed from the specification as leaving it into the US-Core leads to interoperability problems as it provides two similar functionality for no defined benefit or difference.
I suspect the intent of $docref is good. It is just not well enough explained. I understand that as an operation the $docref would be more easy to intercept/orchistrate to enable dynamic (on-demand, or delayed-assembly) type documentReference entries). If this is the sole motiviation, then this needs to be more clearly said. If this done, then there must be some further mitigation of why a client would use $docref vs RESTful query; especially as this profile is orchistrated such as in clinical-note.
Further note, this $docref is NOT compliant with IHE-MHD profile. IHE-MHD profile has not received comments asking for an operation.
column17: Further explan the docref operation or remove

column16: The description of $docref is not clear, and indeed less clear than the text found on the DocumentReference page.
column17: Further explain the docref operation or remove
column25: Will improve guidance and provide some background on why we created.  Will update the parameters when merge DocRefereences

column16:
By being an operation there is limitation of query parameters. Thus this operation will always be behind the needs of users.
For example, a new need for category (class) parameter.

column16:
consider adding more parameters as recommendations (This list from MHD). I don't expect these all to be in US-Core, just wanted to clearly identify the gap: 
* status - as it is often important to make clear the client is not interested in non-current entries
* date - as the publication date is sometimes known
* author - as sometimes the client knows who the author was
*category  - category is a more query friendly due to the nature of a smaller grouping valueset
* setting - the practice setting from which the document came
* facility - the type of facility that published the document
* event  - to find documents related to an event
* related - similarly to find documents related to an event id (e.g. assession)
* format - the specific type of technical format of the document
==> most pressing is category and status.
column17: Add search parameters to DocumentReference search
column25: Will add status and category as recommended parameters

column16:
This first requirement of the security section seems to have text problems "requirementsocumented". This first sentence also seems to indicate that there are security requirements documented in "this IG", yet it is unclear what "this" is refering to. Is this simply the US-Core, or is "this" intended to be a link to a different IG?
The problem might simply need more accurate english language.

column25: Will fix.

column14: A server has ensured that every API request includes a valid Authorization token, supplied via: Authorization: Bearer {server-specific-token-here}
column16: This second requirement of the security section seems to be too specific. Binding this specific of a security requirement into US-Core will force a new IG to be written when a new security is needed. Far better US-Core set broad security requirements (such as #3), and recommend us of security IG like SMART-on-FHIR. In this way as SMART evolves those enhancements are available; or as new IG are written for specific security settings they can be used with US-Core without breaking US-Core. (See security considerations section of IHE profiles like MHD)
column17: Update security requirements to reference SMART on FHIR
column25: Will update to reference SMART on FHIR

column14:
The US Core Client SHOULD:

Support fetching and querying of one or more US Core profile(s), using the supported RESTful interactions and search parameters declared in the US Core Server CapabilityStatement.
column15:
The US Core Client SHALL:

Support fetching and querying of one or more US Core profile(s), using the supported RESTful interactions and search parameters declared in the US Core Server CapabilityStatement.
column16: why is this only a SHOULD? This seems to be best said as a SHALL. Otherwise a client can claim to be conformant by just implementing the security requirements. Is that really what is intended?
column17: Make client query support of at least one resource mandatory
column25: Will update to SHALL.

column14:
A client SHOULDe capable of connecting to a server and fetching all of a patient’s DocumentReferences for a given time period and document type:

GET [base]/DocumentReference?patient=[id]&type=[type]&period=[date]{&date=[date]}
column16:
There are a number of places where the search criteria for date period is specified such as:
    …   &period=[date]{&date=[date]}
Yet never is the trailing "{&date=[date]}" explained.
Often the text will simply reference the search on date text in FHIR, yet that text does not have this trailing "{&date=[date]}" said or explained.
Please explain this period/date search (and get that clarification into FHIR R5)
column17: Clarify the additional date search
column25: Will either explain the date search or update reference to FHIR core (if one exists!)

column16: While I realize this section presents a minimal required set of seach operations, I would recommend either including search by status, class, and/or type as part of that set or introducing a 'preferred' conformance set to the Encounter profile  that go beyond the minimal mandatory set. Not doing so requires fetching a potentially large set of encounters and filtering when looking for specific types of encounters.

column14: Diagnosis Role value set is preferred

column25: Diagnosis is an optional element in the existing US Core Encounter resource. If further testing occurs, we could consider increasing the binding strength

column14:
Current Diagnosis Role value set elements:
> Admission diagnosis
> Discharge diagnosis
> Chief complaint
> Comorbidity diagnosis
> Pre-op diagnosis
> Post-op diagnosis
> Billing
Cardinality: 0..1
column15:
Cardinality should be 0..*.  These can overlap.  E.g., a diagnosis may be both a discharge and billing diagnosis.

Clarify what a "comorbidity diagnosis" is.  Since a diagnosis is almost by definition a comorbidity, this seems redundant.

Add in elements needed for quality measures such as for HEDIS, CMS: Present-on-admission diagnosis, and as subset of billing - facility billing diagnosis, professional billing diagnosis.  Rename billing to billing diagnosis.

column16: In cases where mutiple codes are expected to be useful for a search parameter, require support for that (e.g., multiple codes for DiagnosticReport -- this is currently SHOULD only). This would reduce latency.  Examples include DiagnosticReport.category, DiagnosticReport.code, DocumentReference.class, DocumentReference.type.
column17: Add multi-valued search parameters where applicable
column25: Combinations that the guide requires are helpful to the implementation community. The other combinations are ok and will be added as SHOULD in the CapabilityStatement

column16: In cases where date search parameters can reduce latency, require support for that.  This would apply to any query where the amount of data returned could be large (e.g., all labs or vitals of a common type, all medications, all documents of a common type, etc.).  Examples include DiagnosticReport, DocumentReference, Condition.
column17: Add date search parameters to reduce latency
column25: Condition not date dependent nor is this element listed nor is the search parameter prohibited.  DiagnosticReport has a date parameter already. Index creation date is not likely useful for searching

column16: Instead of enumerating the specific combinations of query parmaters that are required, identify the individual query paramters that must be supported.  E.g., instead of saying -- DiagnosticReport must support search by "patient + category", "patient + code", and "patient + category + date", require that searches must support searches by patient, category, code, and date.  Without this, for example, it is implied that an EHR does not need to support "patient + code + date" as a search pattern, even though what an EHR must implement to support the enumerated combinations would imply that there should be little additional effort to support that specific combination.  Further restrictions could still be added -- such as that "patient" must always be in the query. Comments applies to all US Core FHIR profiles.
column17: Enumerate required search paramters rather than specific combinations of search parameters
column25: Combinations that the guide requires are helpful to the implementation community. The other combinations are ok and will be added as SHOULD in the CapabilityStatement

column16: Where status is required in a US Core profile, require support for search by status.  Examples include DiagnosticReport, DocumentReference, AllergyIntolerance.

column16: Support MedicationDispense in US Core.  Important, e.g., for PDMP management for tackling the opioid crisis.

column25: MedicationDispense is defined in the US Meds implementation guide (https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/FHIR-ONC-Meds/profiles.html). If there is significant support it will be considred for a future version of US Core.

column16: In particular for resources with overlapping scope (and therefore potential for duplicate representation of the same content across queries for different resoruces), provide a unique source instance identifier that can be used to de-duplicate the data.  E.g., for medications, we may need to check MedicationStatement to capture patient-reported meds, and MedicationRequest to capture the dispense quantity for prescriptions.  But the same prescription could show up in both MedicationStatement and MedicationRequest, even though there is only one instance of that data in the source EHR.  Require, or at least note using SHOULD language, that source EHR data instance identifiers are provided so that de-duplication of data can be conducted.
column17: Provide source EHR instance identifiers to allow de-duplication when the same EHR data is used to provide data across multiple FHIR resources with overlapping scope.

column14: Current US Core Condition Category Codes: problem-list-item, encounter-diagnosis, and health-concern
column15: Add categories for past-medical-history and chief-complaint
column16: Past Medical History is a common place where conditions are managed, and is separate from Problem List in at least one major EHR; chief-complaint is needed for support in Encounter.diagnosis.
column17: Add Past Medical History and Chief Complaint to condition types.
column21: Chief complaint is relevant within the existance of an Encounter and is available in the Encounter Resource. Prior conditions can be included, or a narrative note can include a Past Medical History .

column16: Currently, a lot of important elements of an encounter diagnosis are available only via Encounter searches.  This makes it very inefficient  to ask things like -- has anybody ever given this patient a billing encounter diagnosis for pancreatic cancer?  Because it would entail seeking and going through every Encounter the patient has ever had (since the identification of the encounter diagnosis as a billing item is only available in Encounter.diagnosis, of which Condition is a part).  Take the other attributes in Encounter.diagnosis and make them attributes of Condition, so that relevant details of encounter diagnoses can be searched direclty via Conditions.

column16: EHR implementations that are represented as US Core profile compliant may not be.  Recommend working with relevant stakeholders to develop a robust compliance testing mechanism for US Core.
column17: Compliance testing
column25: Thank you for the suggestion - work is being done in the Inferno tool to support US Core to help evaluate system support.  As well, the ig produces all the artifacts to support profile validation.  The Construction of a validation infrastrure is outside the scope of this project.

column16: Recommend adding support, when available in the EHR, on information on years since quit smoking (if quit) and information needed to determine pack-year history.  This information is needed to determine if a patient is a candidate for lung cancer screening; lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths, and more appropriate lung cancer screening is projected to save more lives than breast cancer screening, but current screening rates in the U.S. is < 5%.  We have implemented support for this at our Epic EHR implementation and can share the specification for this purpose.
column17: Consider adding years since quite smoking
column25: While this seems like an important element, additional testing and verification from other EHR/FHIR servers is needed before being added to US Core.

column16: The name, DiagnosticReport, seems inappropriate as a description of the types of clinical notes that must be supported. One could argue that none of the notes that must be supported would be considered to be a diagnostic report. This seems likely to cause a great deal of confusion for implementers. Whay not name the resource ClinicalNote?
column17: The name, DiagnosticReport, seems inappropriate as a description of the types of clinical notes that must be supported. One could argue that none of the notes that must be supported would be considered to be a diagnostic report. This seems likely to cause a great deal of confusion for implementers. Whay not name the resource ClinicalNote?
column25:
Patient Care considered a new Clinical Notes Resource but struggled with the overlap on existing resources. 

The discussion on the clinical-notes-guidance.html page is intended to describe the need for DiagnosticReport vs DocumentReference. There are several formats of notes 'PDF', 'XHTML', 'CDA' and using a resource that indexes clinical note content helps implementers (clients) find notes without querying lots of resources. Consider a lab report that has both narrative and discrete content vs a scanned report. Should that be a 'Clinical Note' or a DiagnosticReport?
